text: I swallow the sound of the door bar and slip on my coat before following her out. The night wind cuts like a blade; snow pellets sting as they strike my face.
She moves fast without looking back—as if she already assumes I’ll follow, or as if she’s betting that I won’t.
I keep my steps light, careful not to let my boots scrape the ice. It’s strange—I’ve never trained for stealth, yet my body moves like it’s done this countless times before.
“Stay close.”
“I won’t slow you down.”
She doesn’t answer. Instead, she flicks the edge of her cloak back slightly so I can see the route in her hand—not streets, but gaps.
We bypass two well-lit roads and slip into an alley no one uses. Ice crusts the iron spikes along the walls like a row of teeth. There’s a faint smell of something burned.
“Echo Circle operatives are inside.”
“What do you want me to do?”
She finally turns her face toward me. The look is brief—an evaluation of whether I deserve to live another second.
“Hold the alley mouth.”
“If anyone runs out—don’t fight. Call my name.”
“That’s it?”
“That’s it.”
She presses a small bundle into my hand—cold, gritty powder, hard as ground bone.
“Listen carefully.”
“What you’re doing isn’t ‘fighting.’ It’s ‘don’t let them register you as a target.’”
She turns and disappears into the dark. Her cloak flashes once—like a slit cut into falling snow.
From deep inside the alley comes the faintest sound of metal—short, precise, like a conversation being deleted mid-sentence.
I press my back to the wall and force myself not to move. All I can hear is my heartbeat and the snow falling.
Suddenly, a figure staggers out of the alley. Black robe. A dark ring stained across his chest.
“Stop!”
I don’t rush him. I scatter the powder at his feet instead—the moment it hits the snow, thin white smoke curls upward.
His step falters. He doubles over, coughing. In the next instant, a streak of silver cuts out from the alley.
“Don’t touch him.”
Her blade stops at his throat—clean, exact, like the ending was written ahead of time.
He tries to speak. She twists her wrist—and he never makes another sound.
Alicia pulls a thin chain from inside his collar. The pendant flashes once in the firelight.
“Not it.”
She frowns, like time has been wasted. Then she looks at me, her voice low but clear.
“You did well.”
The praise is brief, but it lands like permission. She tucks the chain inside her cloak.
“Move. Next location.”
